column1: Ellicott City's historic downtown – the Ellicott City Historic District – lies in the valleys of the Tiber and Patapsco rivers. The historic district includes the Ellicott City Station
column2: which is the oldest surviving train station in the United States
column3: having been built in 1830 as the first terminus of the original B&O Railroad line. The historic district is often called "Historic Ellicott City" or "Old Ellicott City" to distinguish it from the surrounding suburbs that extend south to Columbia and west to West Friendship.

column2: James Hood used the "Maryland Mill Act of 1669" to condemn 20 acres (8.1 ha) for a mill site adjacent to his river-side 157-acre (64 ha) property. His gristmill was built on the banks of the Patapsco River where the Frederick road (later known as the National Road
column3: then U.S. Route 40
column4: then Maryland Route 144) crossed the river. The site was later known as "Ellicott's Upper Mills". His son Benjamin rebuilt the corn grinding mill after one of the frequent Patapsco floods in 1768. Benjamin Hood then sold the mill to Joseph Ellicott in 1774 for 1
column5: 700 pounds. In later years the B&O Railroad ran through the property
column6: with track laid over the graves of the Hood family.On 24 April 1771
column7: three Quaker brothers from Bucks County
column8: Pennsylvania
column10: chose the picturesque wilderness several miles upriver from Elk Ridge Landing (today's Elkridge
column12: the uppermost part of the river then navigable by tobacco-loading sailing merchant ships in the 18th century

column17: which became one of the largest milling and manufacturing towns in the East. Nathaniel sold his partnership in 1777
column18: and Joseph sold all but his Hood's Mill ownership the next year. The town retained the name "Ellicott's Mills" when the U.S. Postal stop opened on October 7

They helped revolutionize farming in the area by persuading farmers to plant wheat instead of tobacco and also by introducing Plaster of Paris fertilizer to revitalize depleted soil. The Ellicotts produced the product until a fire on 11 January 1809. Charles Carroll of Carrollton (1737-1832)
column7: the last surviving signer of the Declaration of Independence
column8: a rare Roman Catholic and a wealthy landowner with the largest fortune then in colonial America
column9: was an early influential convert from tobacco to wheat. By 1830

column2: Ellicott's Mills became the first terminus of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad outside Baltimore
column3: the first commercially operated cargo and passenger railroad in the country. The B&O was organized in 1827 and had its "first stone" laid the following year with major ceremonies on July 4
column4: Independence Day
column5: with the beginning of construction. The Ellicott City Station
column6: built on an embankment across the corner of the town and along the Patapsco River and intersecting Tiber Creek stream
column7: with its "Oliver Viaduct"
column8: named for a B&O board member Robert Oliver crossing over the National Road of large blocks of locally quarried gray granite
column9: stands today as a living history museum
column10: and has been designated a National Historic Landmark by the U.S. Department of the Interior
column11: administered by the National Park Service. It bears the designation as the "Oldest surviving railroad station in America". In 1829
column12: New York industrialist and Baltimore foundry-owner Peter Cooper began testing his iron steam engine
column14: on the B&O Railway. This was the first time a steam locomotive was used to transport persons over rails in the United States. The famous race between Tom Thumb and a horse-drawn rail carriage took place between Relay Junction on the return trip from Ellicott's Mills towards Baltimore in August 1830. Even though the horse won the race due to a sudden broken drive belt on the Tom Thumb
column15: it heralded the time when steam engines steadily improved
column16: and the soon-to-be steam-operated railroad became a vital link in the town's economy and later expanding to the city of Baltimore's economic supremacy along with the state in the nation.

column1: The site of the Howard County Courthouse

column6: as one of the 23 counties (plus Baltimore as an independent city) in the state of Maryland. The town in 1851 was in a spate of depression as low costs shut the Maryland Machine Manufacturing Company. Over 80 vacant dwellings lined the Howard County side of the river. By 1861
column7: Ellicott's Mills was a prosperous farming and manufacturing area.

column1: At the start of the Civil War on April 19
column3: "Gaithers Raiders"

column5: marched through Ellicott's Mills to Baltimore
column6: responding to the Baltimore riot of 1861

column8: Union Army troops seized the "Winans Steam Gun" which had been en route to Harpers Ferry
column10: at Ellicott's Mills. The experimental gun had been developed by local Southern-sympathizer railroad builder and industrialist Ross Winans. In the fall of 1862

column15: the third Confederate invasion of the North
column17: forced the retreat of the Federal troops under the command of General Lew Wallace down the National Pike from the Battle of the Monocacy to the B.& O.'s Ellicott's Mills station and to Baltimore. The one-day delay by Wallace's small force at Monocacy Junction enabled Lt. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant to rush troops in time to defend the U.S. capital. Homes and churches in Ellicott's Mills were temporarily used as hospitals for the Union wounded.In 1866

column2: a city incorporation charter was secured for Ellicott's Mills forming a local government with a mayor and council
column3: and the name was changed to "Ellicott City".The first mayor was E.A. Talbot

column6: which he did. Talbot relocated uphill to a brick and granite store designed by Charles Timanus that houses the Ellicott City Brewing Company today.

Governor Brown condemned the citizens and ordered all prisoners sentenced to death be sent to the Maryland Penitentiary from then on.After a difficult start in 1896
column22: Taylor Manor started as the Patapsco Manor Sanitarium built on property along New Cut Road. In 1939 the facility was purchased by Issac Taylor and run as the Pinel Clinic. Taylor operated an optometrist business and Taylor's Furniture on Main Street. In 1948 the facility expanded to 48 beds
column23: and in 1968 it expanded to 151 beds. The modernist circular rotunda stands out at the center of campus. Taylor Manor covered more than 70 acres (28 ha). In 2000
column24: the facility became a branch of Sheppard and Enoch Pratt Hospital.

column1: Ellicott City has been home to a large Korean population along its Route 40 corridor
column2: where numerous Korean-owned businesses and restaurants operate. Around 12
column3: 000 Korean-Americans currently live in Howard County

column1: The town is prone to flooding from the Patapsco River and its tributary the Tiber River. These floods have had a major impact on the history of the town
column2: often destroying important businesses and killing many. Ellicott City has had major devastating floods in 1817
column17: and 2018. The 1868 flood washed away 14 houses
column18: killing 39 to 43 (accounts vary) in and around Ellicott City. It wiped out the Granite Manufacturing Cotton Mill
column21: and dozens of homes. One mill was rebuilt by Charles Gambrill
column22: which remained in operation until a fire in 1916.

column3: and a 1956 flood inflicted heavy damage at the Bartigis Brothers plant. On June 21

column7: destroying the Jonathan Ellicott home
column8: and the 1910 Victor Blode water filtration plant
column9: and flooding Main Street to the Odd Fellows hall. The Old Main Line of the B&O Railroad also sustained serious damage.

column1: In 2017 the Ellicott City Watershed Master Plan was unveiled but after the 2018 flood the plans had to be re-evaluated. A $140 million multi-tiered five-year plan was chosen by County officials. The plan includes building a tunnel requiring the removal of nine historic structures.The removal of nine or ten historic buildings was opposed by preservationists as well as residents and Democrat Calvin Ball defeated incumbent Republican Allan Kittleman as county executive. Ball halted the work of Kittleman to study five plans. One would involve removing six buildings and another only four buildings. Two plans called for boring underground tunnels that was considered too expensive.The plan chosen involves tearing down four buildings and boring a 15-foot diameter tunnel through 1
column2: 600 feet of the granite hillside. Ten buildings were purchased and six will be stabilized and restored. The plan is not to solve the flood problem but mitigate it down from over four feet to under one foot of flooding on the streets.

column1: Ellicott City is in northeastern Howard County
column2: bordered to the east and north by the Patapsco River
column3: which forms the Baltimore County line. The Ellicott City census-designated place (CDP) extends to the northwest beyond Marriottsville Road and to the southwest beyond Centennial Road. It is bordered to the south by Columbia at Maryland Route 108 and to the southeast by Ilchester at Maryland Route 104 and Bonnie Branch Road. According to the United States Census Bureau
column4: the CDP has a total area of 30.1 square miles (77.9 km2)
column5: of which 30.0 square miles (77.6 km2) are land and 0.1 square miles (0.3 km2)
column7: are water.Ellicott City is claimed to be built on seven hills. These hills lie southeast of the Historic District
column8: which is in the Tiber River valley immediately west of the Patapsco River. The Tiber River is a small tributary of the Patapsco that forms the narrow valley followed by Main Street. Several deep stream valleys converge at this location
column9: which increases the risk of flooding
column10: but at the same time creates the town's heights.The heart of the Historic District is Main Street
column11: where the oldest structures of the town stand. Smaller neighborhoods within the district include Tongue Row adjacent to Old Columbia Pike
column13: at the western end of Main Street.

Historic Ellicott City sits on the Silurian or Ordovician Ellicott City Granodiorite.  Outcrops can be seen lining Main Street. Several granite quarries were in operation in Ellicott City in the late 1800s and early 1900s.

column2: with frequent thunderstorms. Spring and fall bring pleasant temperatures. Winter is often considered chilly by U.S. standards
column3: with lighter rain showers of longer duration. Sporadic snowfall can occur in winter
column4: but is usually relatively light. The Köppen classification is humid subtropical. Rainfall is spread evenly throughout the year
column5: with 3–5 inches (76–127 mm) falling each month.

column1: Ellicott City is served by the Regional Transportation Agency of Central Maryland (RTA) by Route 405 (Yellow Line) travelling from the Columbia Mall to the Miller Branch Public Library. The Maryland Transit Administration also provides commuter bus service via Lines 150 and 345. Dorsey station is the nearest MARC Train
column2: located 9 miles away in Elkridge. The station is accessed off of Route 100 and is equipped with over 800 spaces.

column1: Numerous paths and trails surround Ellicott City for recreational and commuting purposes. The Grist Mill Trail in Patapsco Valley State Park runs parallel to the Patapsco River in Baltimore County
column2: connecting Ilchester Road to Gun Road in Relay. The trail is known for the Patapsco Swinging Bridge. The Trolley Line Number 9 Trail in nearby Oella also connects Ellicott City to Catonsville.
